1.title: Simple Present
1.content:
The Simple Present is used to describe habits, general truths, repeated actions, or unchanging situations, emotions, and wishes. It describes facts and scheduled events.

Structure (Affirmative):

Subject + Base Verb (+s/es)

Structure (Negative):

Subject + do/does not + Base Verb

Structure (Question):

Do/Does + Subject + Base Verb?

Examples:

  • This function returns an array of objects.
  • We have a daily stand-up meeting at 9 AM.
  • The new module doesn't handle that specific case.
  • Does the script run automatically?
  • APIs provide a way for systems to communicate.
  • The build process takes about five minutes.

2.title: Subject Questions
2.content:
A Subject Question asks about the doer or performer of an action. The question word (like Who, What, or Which) is the subject of the sentence.

The key rule is that we do not use auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The sentence structure is like a normal statement.

Structure:

Question Word (as Subject) + Main Verb + (Object)?

Examples:

  • Who implemented this feature?
  • What causes this conflict?
  • Which team has the latest code?
  • Who needs access to the repository?
  • What went wrong during the deployment?

Common Mistake (vs. Object Question):

- Who did implement this? (Incorrect use of auxiliary)
- Who implemented this? (Correct)

3.title: Object Questions
3.content:
An Object Question asks about the receiver of an action. The subject is known, and the question word (like What, Who, or Which) asks about the object.

The key rule is that we must use an auxiliary verb (do, does, did, will, have, etc.) in most tenses. The structure requires subject-verb inversion.

Structure:

Question Word (as Object) + Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • What module did the team modify?
  • Who did you ask?
  • Which report does this change mention?
  • What have you done so far?
  • Which variable should I check?

Common Mistake (vs. Subject Question):

- What the team modified? (Missing auxiliary)
- What did the team modify? (Correct)

4.title: Negative Questions
4.content:
Negative Questions start with a negative auxiliary verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Shouldn't). They are very common in conversation and are typically used in two main ways:

  1. To confirm something you believe is true: You expect the listener to agree with you.
  2. To express surprise, concern, or persuasion: You are highlighting something unexpected or trying to convince someone.

Structure:

Negative Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

12 Common Examples:

  • (Confirmation) Don't you think this is too complex?
  • (Confirmation) Didn't we fix this issue already?
  • (Surprise) Isn't that the file you were looking for?
  • (Confirmation) Aren't those the requirements we agreed on?
  • (Past Expectation) Shouldn't we have tested this edge case?
  • (Surprise) Hasn't he finished his part yet?
  • (Surprise) Haven't you seen the new mockups?
  • (Concern) Won't this change affect the production server?
  • (Persuasion) Can't you just revert the last commit?
  • (Confirmation) Couldn't you find the file in the shared drive?
  • (Suggestion) Wouldn't it be better to wait until Monday?
  • (Expectation) Weren't you supposed to be in that meeting?

5.title: Present Perfect
5.content:
The Present Perfect connects the past with the present. It is used for actions that happened at an unspecified time in the past, or actions that started in the past and continue to the present. The focus is on the result.

Structure:

Subject + have/has + Past Participle

10 Examples:

  • I have finished the report. (Result: It is ready now)
  • She has worked at Google for ten years. (She still works there)
  • We have seen that error before. (Experience)
  • He hasn't completed the task yet.
  • Have you updated the database?
  • They have just launched the new feature.
  • The server has crashed three times today.
  • I have never used that library.
  • She has lost her access keys.
  • Has the client approved the design?

6.title: Present Perfect Continuous
6.content:
Used for actions that started in the past and are still in progress or have recently stopped. It emphasizes the duration or the activity itself, rather than the result.

Structure:

Subject + have/has been + Verb-ing

8 Examples:

  • I have been coding for five hours straight.
  • She has been trying to fix this bug all morning.
  • We have been waiting for the API response for too long.
  • They have been discussing the requirements since yesterday.
  • It has been raining all week.
  • He hasn't been feeling well lately.
  • What have you been doing?
  • The system has been lagging recently.

7.title: Past Perfect
7.content:
The Past Perfect is the 'past of the past'. It is used to show that one action happened before another action in the past. It clarifies the sequence of events.

Structure:

Subject + had + Past Participle

Examples:

  • When I arrived, the meeting had already started.
  • She realized she had forgotten her laptop.
  • We had tested the code before we deployed it.
  • The server crashed because someone had deleted the config file.
  • He had never seen such messy code before that job.
  • By the time they fixed the bug, the users had already complained.
  • I didn't have any money because I had lost my wallet.

8.title: First Conditional
8.content:
The First Conditional is used to talk about real and possible future situations. It describes a likely result if a certain condition is met.

Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... will + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If we finish early, we will deploy the update.
  • If the server goes down, I will call you immediately.
  • You will miss the deadline if you don't start now.
  • She will be late if the train is delayed.
  • If I have time later, I 'll call you.
  • Will you help me if I need it?

9.title: Second Conditional
9.content:
The Second Conditional is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. It describes an imaginary result for an unreal condition.

Structure:

If + Past Simple, ... would + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If I had more time, I would refactor this module.
  • If we had the budget, we would hire another developer.
  • What would you do if you were the project manager?
  • If I were you, I would take the job.
  • Morale would improve if the company gave everyone a bonus.
  • We would travel more if we didn't have kids.

10.title: Third Conditional
10.content:
The Third Conditional is used to talk about hypothetical situations in the past. It describes an imaginary result for a past condition that did not happen. It's often used to express regret.

Structure:

If + Past Perfect, ... would have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • If I had known about the bug, I would have fixed it.
  • If we had tested it better, the system would not have crashed.
  • They would have finished on time if the requirements hadn't changed.
  • If you had told me, I would have helped you.
  • She wouldn't have been so tired if she had gone to bed earlier.
  • Would you have accepted the offer if they had offered more money?

11.title: Modal Perfects
11.content:
Modal Perfects (modal + have + past participle) are used to speculate, judge, or discuss possibilities and unfulfilled actions in the past. They allow us to express how we feel about a past event.

Breakdown of Meanings:

  • Should have: Expresses regret or criticism about a past action. It was the 'right' thing to do, but it didn't happen.
  • Could have: Expresses an unrealized past possibility or opportunity. The action was possible, but it wasn't taken.
  • Must have / Can't have: Expresses a logical deduction. 'Must have' for high certainty something happened; 'Can't have' for high certainty it did not.
  • Would have: Used for the result of a hypothetical past condition (3rd Conditional) or a past willingness that was not acted upon.
  • Might / May have: Expresses a past possibility with less certainty than 'must have'.

Structure:

Subject + modal + have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • (Regret) I should have saved my work before the computer crashed.
  • (Criticism) You shouldn't have deployed without running the tests.
  • (Possibility) We could have finished yesterday, but we ran into an issue.
  • (Deduction +) The server is down. Someone must have restarted it.
  • (Deduction -) He can't have finished already; he only started an hour ago.
  • (Conditional) If I had known, I would have helped you.
  • (Speculation) She's late. She might have gotten stuck in traffic.
  • (Past Willingness) I would have joined the meeting, but I had another commitment.
  • (Lost Opportunity) You could have caused a major system failure with that command.
  • (Uncertain Possibility) The data corruption may have been a network error, but we're not sure.

12.title: The Passive Voice
12.content:
The Passive Voice is used when the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, not on the person who performs it (the agent). It is very common in technical and formal writing.

When to Use:

  • When the agent (doer) is unknown. (e.g., 'The server was hacked.')
  • When the agent is irrelevant. (e.g., 'The component is rendered.')
  • When you want to be formal and impersonal. (e.g., 'It is recommended that...')

Structure:

Receiver + be (conjugated) + Past Participle + (by Agent)

Examples:

  • The new feature was implemented last week.
  • The server is being restarted right now.
  • This report must be finished by tomorrow.
  • The data has been retrieved successfully.
  • The old code will be refactored by the senior developer.

13.title: Gerunds (-ing) vs. Infinitives (to + verb)
13.content:
Whether you use a gerund or an infinitive after a verb depends on the first verb. There is no logical rule for this; you must memorize which group the verb belongs to.

Group A: Verbs followed by Gerunds (-ing)

avoid, enjoy, finish, suggest, mind, keep, consider, recommend, discuss, miss

  • We should avoid deploying on Fridays.
  • She suggested using a different library.
  • I finished writing the tests.
  • Please keep monitoring the logs.
  • He doesn't mind helping you.

Group B: Verbs followed by Infinitives (to + verb)

want, need, decide, hope, plan, agree, promise, afford, learn, refuse

  • I decided to refactor the code.
  • We need to update the database.
  • They plan to launch next week.
  • She hopes to finish by 5 PM.
  • The client agreed to extend the deadline.

14.title: Gerunds after Prepositions
14.content:
Rule: If a verb follows a preposition (in, on, at, of, for, about, without, etc.), it must be a Gerund (-ing).

Examples:

  • He is good at solving problems.
  • I'm interested in learning React.
  • Thank you for helping me.
  • You can't leave without saying goodbye.
  • We talked about redesigning the website.
  • She is tired of working overtime.
  • Instead of complaining, let's fix it.
  • He apologized for being late.

15.title: Used to vs. Be used to
15.content:
These two expressions are easily confused but have completely different meanings and grammatical structures.

Structure:

Past Habit (no longer true):
Subject + used to + Base Verb

Accustomed to (familiar with):
Subject + be (conjugated) + used to + Gerund (-ing) / Noun

Examples: 'Be used to' (Accustomed to)

  • He is a chef, so he is used to working under pressure.
  • After three months, I am finally used to waking up early.
  • They live near the airport, so they are used to the noise.
  • She isn't used to using this software yet.
  • Are you used to driving in the city now?

Examples: 'Used to' (Past Habit)

  • I used to live in a small town.
  • We used to play outside for hours when we were kids.
  • She didn't use to like coffee, but now she loves it.
  • He used to have long hair.
  • Did you use to work with him at your old company?

16.title: Phrasal Verbs
16.content:
A Phrasal Verb is a combination of a verb and a particle (a preposition or adverb). The meaning of this combination is often idiomatic and very different from the individual words. Mastering them is essential for sounding natural in English.

Some phrasal verbs are separable, meaning an object can go in the middle (e.g., 'turn the light off').

Common Examples:

  • Give up (to quit/stop trying)
    Don't give up on your goals.
  • Take off (to leave the ground; to remove clothing)
    The plane will take off in five minutes.
  • Look after (to take care of)
    Can you look after my cat this weekend?
  • Run out of (to exhaust a supply)
    We ran out of milk this morning.
  • Put up with (to tolerate)
    I can't put up with that noise anymore.
  • Turn down (to reject an offer; to lower volume)
    She had to turn down the job offer.
  • Get over (to recover from an illness or disappointment)
    It took him a long time to get over the breakup.
  • Break down (to stop functioning)
    My car broke down on the highway.

17.title: False Friends (Spanish/English)
17.content:
False Friends are words in two languages that look or sound similar but have different meanings. They are a common source of mistakes for native Spanish speakers.

Common Examples:

  • Actually (EN: in fact, really) ≠ 'Actualmente' (ES: currently)
  • Assist (EN: to help) ≠ 'Asistir' (ES: to attend)
  • Attend (EN: to be present at) ≠ 'Atender' (ES: to help, to serve)
  • Library (EN: biblioteca) ≠ 'Librería' (ES: bookstore)
  • Success (EN: éxito) ≠ 'Suceso' (ES: event)
  • Realize (EN: to become aware) ≠ 'Realizar' (ES: to carry out, to do)
  • Sensible (EN: practical, reasonable) ≠ 'Sensible' (ES: sensitive)
  • Fabric (EN: tela) ≠ 'Fábrica' (ES: factory)
  • Resume (EN: to continue) ≠ 'Resumir' (ES: to summarize)

18.title: Make vs. Do
18.content:
While both verbs relate to actions, they are not interchangeable. The key difference lies in the outcome: DO is for tasks and activities, while MAKE is for creating or producing a result.

When to use DO

Use DO for tasks, obligations, and general activities that do not produce a new physical object.

  • We need to do business with that new client.
  • Could you do me a favor and review this code?
  • I have to do the laundry this afternoon.
  • She always encourages me to do my best.
  • You should do some research before the meeting.
  • He did a good job on the presentation.

When to use MAKE

Use MAKE for actions related to creating, producing, or causing a result or reaction.

  • The team needs to make a decision by Friday.
  • He was asked to make a suggestion to improve the workflow.
  • I have to make a phone call before we start.
  • Try not to make a mistake in the final report.
  • This new feature will make a big difference.
  • She made a good point in the meeting.

19.title: Modal Verbs: Future Equivalents
19.content:
Modals like can, must, and may do not have a future tense. To express these concepts in the future, we use substitute phrases with 'will'.

Structure:

Can → will be able to
Must → will have to
Allowed → will be allowed to

Examples:

  • Tomorrow, we will be able to access the new server.
  • You will have to reset your password soon.
  • She won't be able to attend the meeting next week.
  • When will I be able to download the file?
  • If the test fails, we will have to rewrite the code.
  • Users won't be allowed to view this page without admin rights.
  • Hopefully, they will be able to fix it by tomorrow.

20.title: Possessive Nouns ('s)
20.content:
Add 's to singular nouns. Add only ' to plural nouns ending in 's'.

Examples:

  • This is John's car.
  • The cat's toy is under the sofa.
  • My parents' house is big. (Plural)
  • The children's park. (Irregular plural)
  • James's (or James') bag.
  • The company's policy.
  • Where is the men's room?
  • I need my boss's approval.

21.title: Prepositions of Time: In, On, At
21.content:
IN: Months, Years, Centuries, Parts of Day.
ON: Days, Dates.
AT: Exact times, Festivals, 'Night'.

Examples:

  • In 1990 / In July.
  • In the morning / In the 21st century.
  • On Monday / On July 4th.
  • On my birthday / On the weekend (US).
  • At 5:00 PM / At noon.
  • At night / At Christmas.
  • At the moment.

22.title: Prepositions of Place: In, On, At
22.content:
These prepositions refer to location. Use IN for enclosed spaces/large areas, ON for surfaces, and AT for specific points or locations.

Structure:

IN [Enclosed Space / Large Area]
ON [Surface]
AT [Specific Point / Location]

Examples:

  • The connection string is in the configuration file.
  • I live in London.
  • The logo is on the main page.
  • My laptop is on the desk.
  • Let's meet at the whiteboard.
  • He is waiting at the bus stop.

23.title: Adjective vs. Adverb
23.content:
Adjectives describe nouns. Adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs (usually ending in -ly).

Examples:

  • (Adj) She is a quick learner.
  • (Adv) She learns quickly.
  • (Adj) The code is bad.
  • (Adv) The code runs badly.
  • (Adj) He is a careful driver.
  • (Adv) He drives carefully.
  • (Adv) It is extremely important. (Modifying adjective)
  • (Irregular) He is a good cook. / He cooks well.
  • (Irregular) It is a fast car. / It goes fast.

24.title: Still vs. Yet
24.content:
Still implies continuity (something hasn't stopped). Yet implies expectation (something hasn't happened... but will).

Structure:

Still → Mid-position (usually).
Yet → End-position (Negative/Question).

Examples:

  • I still have a lot of work to do.
  • Is it still raining?
  • We haven't finished the project yet.
  • Has the email arrived yet?
  • I am still waiting for a response.
  • The bus hasn't come yet.
  • Do you still live in Chile?
  • No, not yet.

25.title: So vs. Such
25.content:
Both are intensifiers. So is used with adjectives/adverbs. Such is used with Nouns (or Adjective + Noun).

Structure:

So + Adjective
Such + (a/an) + (Adj) + Noun

Examples:

  • The test was so hard.
  • It was such a hard test.
  • He drives so fast.
  • It is such a nice day!
  • They are such friendly people. (Plural - no 'a')
  • Why are you so angry?
  • I've never seen such messy code.
  • It was so expensive that I didn't buy it.

26.title: Ago vs. For
26.content:
Ago is used with Past Simple to say 'how far back' in time. For describes a duration of time.

Examples:

  • I arrived 10 minutes ago. (Point in past)
  • I have waited for 10 minutes. (Duration)
  • We started the project two years ago.
  • We have worked on this for two years.
  • Dinosaurs lived millions of years ago.
  • He slept for 8 hours.
  • She left a long time ago.

27.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
27.content:
We use comparatives to compare two things and superlatives to compare three or more things (or one thing against a whole group).

1. Comparatives (2 items)

Short: Adj + -er + than
Long: more + Adj + than

  • This API is faster than the old one.
  • Python is easier to learn than C++.
  • The new server is more powerful than the previous one.
  • Cloud storage is usually cheaper than maintaining local servers.
  • Today is hotter than yesterday.
  • My code is messier than yours.

2. Superlatives (3+ items / Group)

Short: the + Adj + -est
Long: the + most + Adj

  • This is the most difficult task in the project.
  • That was the worst bug I have ever seen. (Irregular)
  • React is the most used library right now.
  • Please choose the most efficient algorithm.
  • The furthest node is offline.
  • He is the best developer on the team. (Irregular)

28.title: Adjective Order
28.content:
The general order is: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Color - Origin - Material - Purpose + NOUN.

Examples:

  • A lovely old red car.
  • A big square wooden table.
  • A beautiful Italian leather jacket.
  • A small black plastic bag.
  • An expensive new German sports car.
  • It's a delicious hot soup.

29.title: Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns
29.content:
Countable nouns can be counted (one bug, two bugs) and use quantifiers like 'many' or 'a few'. Uncountable nouns cannot be counted (information, software, advice) and use 'much' or 'a little'.

Structure:

many / a few + [Countable Noun]
much / a little + [Uncountable Noun]

Countable Examples:

  • How many tickets are open?
  • We have a few options.
  • There are three servers in the cluster.

Uncountable Examples:

  • How much progress have we made?
  • We need a little more information.
  • He gave me some good advice.

30.title: Articles: A/An vs. The
30.content:
A/An is for general/unknown things (one of many). The is for specific/known things (the only one, or one mentioned before).

Examples:

  • I need a pen. (Any pen will do)
  • I need the pen that is on your desk. (Specific)
  • She bought a new car.
  • The car she bought is red.
  • Can I ask a question?
  • What is the answer to question 5?
  • He is an engineer.
  • The sun is hot. (Unique)
  • We have a problem with the server.

31.title: Zero Article (No Article)
31.content:
Do not use 'the' for general plural nouns, abstract nouns, names of people/cities/countries (mostly), or meals.

Examples:

  • Dogs are friendly. (All dogs)
  • I love music. (Abstract)
  • He lives in Japan.
  • She speaks English.
  • We are having lunch.
  • Money doesn't buy happiness.
  • President Smith is speaking.
  • I go to school by bus.

32.title: Too vs. Enough
32.content:
Too = More than necessary (Negative). Enough = Sufficient (Positive). Note the position.

Structure:

Too + Adjective
Adjective + Enough
Enough + Noun

Examples:

  • The coffee is too hot. I can't drink it.
  • He isn't old enough to drive.
  • I don't have enough time.
  • You are working too slowly.
  • This laptop is too expensive.
  • Is the room warm enough?
  • There are too many bugs in this code.
  • We have enough developers for the project.

33.title: Connectors of Contrast
33.content:
These words connect contrasting ideas. The grammar rules for what follows the connector are strict.

Group 1: Followed by a Clause (Subject + Verb)

Although / Even though / While / Whereas + [Subject + Verb]

  • Although the code works, it is not efficient.
  • Even though we tested it, a bug appeared.
  • He likes Java, whereas I prefer Python.
  • While the migration is complex, it is necessary.

Group 2: Followed by a Noun or Gerund (-ing)

Despite / In spite of + [Noun / Verb-ing]

  • Despite the delay, we launched on time.
  • In spite of working late, we didn't finish.
  • They continued despite the errors.

Group 3: Connectors between Sentences

Sentence. However / Nevertheless, Sentence.

  • The plan is good. However, we lack resources.
  • The server crashed. Nevertheless, no data was lost.
  • It was expensive. On the other hand, the quality is top-notch.

34.title: Relative Clauses (who, which, that)
34.content:
Relative clauses add information about a noun. The choice of pronoun depends on whether we are talking about a person or a thing.

The Pronouns:

  • Who: For people.
  • Which: For things or animals.
  • That: For people or things (informal/standard).
  • Whose: For possession.

Examples:

  • The developer who wrote this code is a genius.
  • This is the error which caused the crash.
  • I met a woman who works at Microsoft.
  • Where is the file that was on my desktop?
  • The customer whose account was suspended called support.
  • We need a tool which can handle large datasets.
  • He is the one that told me about the job.
  • Companies that ignore security often get hacked.

35.title: Question Tags
35.content:
Short questions at the end of sentences to ask for confirmation. Positive sentence → Negative tag. Negative sentence → Positive tag.

Examples:

  • You are a student, aren't you?
  • He isn't coming, is he?
  • She works here, doesn't she?
  • They didn't finish, did they?
  • You have eaten, haven't you?
  • I am right, aren't I? (Irregular)
  • Let's go, shall we? (Irregular)
  • Sit down, will you? (Imperative)

36.title: Get + Adjective
36.content:
The verb get is frequently used with an adjective to express a change of state. It means 'to become' or 'to start to be'. It implies a process.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Adjective

Examples:

  • I am getting tired of these repetitive tasks.
  • The situation got complicated very quickly.
  • Don't get angry; it's just a minor issue.
  • It is getting late; we should wrap up.
  • He got sick right before the presentation.
  • They are getting ready for the deployment.
  • My coffee has gotten cold.
  • You will get used to the new workflow soon.
  • The user got confused by the new interface.
  • If you don't save, your work might get lost.
  • It gets dark very early in winter.
  • She got excited when she saw the results.

37.title: Had Better
37.content:
Strong advice or warning. It refers to the immediate future, not the past, despite looking like 'had'.

Structure:

Subject + 'd better (not) + Base Verb

Examples:

  • You'd better hurry.
  • We'd better not miss the bus.
  • He'd better tell the truth.
  • You'd better consult a doctor.
  • I'd better go now.
  • They'd better have a good excuse.

38.title: Be Supposed To
38.content:
Used for obligations, expectations, or general beliefs. It often implies the reality is different.

Examples:

  • I am supposed to be at work now.
  • The weather is supposed to be sunny today.
  • You aren't supposed to smoke here.
  • The train was supposed to arrive an hour ago.
  • What am I supposed to do?
  • This movie is supposed to be really good.

39.title: Causative Verbs (let, make, have, get)
39.content:
These verbs show that one person causes another to do an action. The grammar structure changes depending on the verb used.

Structure:

Let/Make/Have + Person + Base Verb
Get + Person + to + Verb

Examples:

  • (Permission) The boss let me leave early.
  • (Force) The error made the system crash.
  • (Force) She makes her kids do their homework.
  • (Assignment) I'll have my assistant call you.
  • (Assignment) We had the engineer inspect the server.
  • (Persuasion) I finally got the code to work.
  • (Persuasion) Can you get him to help us?
  • (Permission) Don't let the session expire.

40.title: Wish / If Only
40.content:
We use wish or if only to talk about things we want to be different. The verb tense 'shifts back' into the past.

Structure:

Present Wish → Use Past Simple
Past Regret → Use Past Perfect

Examples:

  • I wish I had more time. (I don't have time)
  • She wishes she knew Python. (She doesn't know it)
  • If only I wasn't so busy today.
  • I wish the server was faster.
  • (Regret) I wish I hadn't deleted that file.
  • (Regret) If only we had tested it before launch.
  • (Regret) He wishes he had taken the job offer.
  • I wish it would stop raining. (Complaint about future/now)

41.title: Would Rather ('d rather)
41.content:
Would rather (contracted to 'd rather) is used to express a preference for one option over another in a specific situation, not as a general habit. The grammatical structure that follows is key.

Main Structures:

1. Own Preference:
Subject + 'd rather + Base Verb

2. Comparing Options:
S. + 'd rather + [Verb A] + than + [Verb B]

3. Preference about someone else's action (Subjunctive):
S1 + 'd rather + S2 + Past Simple Verb

Key Differences: 'Would Rather' vs. 'Prefer'

Although they express preference, their usage and grammar are different. Understanding this is fundamental.

  • Prefer: Used for general preferences or habits. It's what you like in general.
    I prefer working from home to going to the office.
  • Would Prefer: For specific preferences (like 'would rather'), but it keeps the grammar of 'prefer' (it uses 'to + verb').
    Today I'd prefer to work from home.
  • Would Rather: For specific preferences, but always followed by the base verb (without 'to').
    It's noisy here. I'd rather work from home.

10 Examples with 'Would Rather':

  • (Simple preference) I'm tired. I'd rather stay home tonight.
  • (Comparison) I'd rather finish this now than leave it for tomorrow.
  • (Question) Would you rather have the meeting in the morning or afternoon?
  • (Negative) I'd rather not discuss this topic right now.
  • (Someone else's action - negative) I'd rather you didn't tell anyone about the project yet.
  • (Someone else's action - affirmative) She'd rather he called her back tomorrow.
  • (Technical choice) He'd rather use a simple text editor than a complex IDE.
  • (Question with options) Would they rather deploy on Friday or wait until Monday?
  • (Team negative) We'd rather not change the requirements again.
  • (Delegating) To be honest, I'd rather you handled this particular client.

42.title: Words ending in -ever
42.content:
Indicate 'it doesn't matter' or 'any'.

Examples:

  • Whatever you do, don't give up.
  • You can go wherever you want.
  • Call me whenever you need help.
  • Whoever broke the vase must pay for it.
  • I will buy whichever one is cheaper.
  • However you try to fix it, it won't work.
  • Choose whichever seat you like.

43.title: As long as / Provided that
43.content:
Conditionals meaning 'if' or 'on the condition that'.

Examples:

  • You can borrow my car as long as you drive carefully.
  • Provided that you finish your work, you can leave early.
  • I don't care where we go as long as we are together.
  • He will sign the contract provided that the terms are clear.
  • As long as it doesn't rain, we will play.

44.title: Either/Or and Neither/Nor
44.content:
Used to pair alternatives. Either...or connects two positive choices. Neither...nor connects two negative choices.

Examples:

  • You can either call me or email me.
  • Neither John nor Peter was there.
  • I drink neither coffee nor tea.
  • We can use either React or Vue.
  • Either you finish it, or I will.
  • The solution was neither efficient nor scalable.
  • You must either stay or go.

45.title: Reported Speech: Statements
45.content:
Reported Speech (or Indirect Speech) is used to report what someone else said without quoting them directly. The core principle is shifting the perspective to the past, which requires three key changes:

The 3 Key Changes:

  1. Tense Backshifting: The verb tense 'shifts back' one step into the past. This is the most important rule.
  2. Pronoun/Possessive Changes: Pronouns are adjusted to fit the new perspective (e.g., 'I' becomes 'he/she', 'my' becomes 'his/her').
  3. Time/Place Adverb Changes: Words like 'today' become 'that day', 'tomorrow' becomes 'the next day', and 'here' becomes 'there'.

Tense Transformation Table:

Direct Speech TenseReported Speech Tense
Present Simple
'The API is ready.'		Past Simple
He said the API was ready.
Present Continuous
'I am working on it.'		Past Continuous
She said she was working on it.
Past Simple
'We finished yesterday.'		Past Perfect
They said they had finished the day before.
Present Perfect
'I have fixed the bug.'		Past Perfect
He said he had fixed the bug.
Future (will)
'I will deploy it tomorrow.'		Conditional (would)
She said she would deploy it the next day.
Modal (can)
'I can solve this.'		Modal (could)
He said he could solve that.
Past Perfect
'The script had already run.'		Past Perfect (No Change)
They said the script had already run.

46.title: Reported Speech: Questions
46.content:
When reporting questions, the sentence structure changes from a question (with inversion) to a statement. The verb tense also 'shifts back' just like with statements.

Yes/No Questions:

Use 'if' or 'whether'. The word order becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Are you finished?'
    → Reported: He asked if I was finished.
  • Direct: 'Does it have a cache?'
    → Reported: She asked whether it had a cache.
  • Direct: 'Have you pushed the changes?'
    → Reported: They asked if I had pushed the changes.

Wh- Questions:

Use the original question word (what, where, when, why, how). The word order also becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Where is the file?'
    → Reported: She asked where the file was.
  • Direct: 'What did you change?'
    → Reported: He asked what I had changed.
  • Direct: 'When will the meeting start?'
    → Reported: They asked when the meeting would start.

47.title: Infinitive of Purpose
47.content:
Use to + verb to explain WHY you do something. Do not use 'for' + verb.

Examples:

  • I went to the store to buy milk.
  • She called to invite me to the party.
  • He is studying hard to pass the exam.
  • We use git to manage versions.
  • Click here to download the file.
  • (Incorrect: I went for buy milk)

48.title: Singular 'They'
48.content:
Used when the gender of the person is unknown, irrelevant, or concealed. It uses plural verbs.

Examples:

  • If a customer calls, tell them I'm busy.
  • Someone left their umbrella here.
  • Who was that? I didn't recognize them.
  • Every student should do their best.
  • Nobody thinks they will fail.
  • Ask the teacher what they think.

49.title: Prepositions: For vs. Of
49.content:
For indicates purpose, beneficiary, or duration. Of indicates possession, content, or part of a group.

Examples (FOR):

  • This gift is for you.
  • I bought a new monitor for gaming.
  • We are waiting for the bus.
  • I spoke for 20 minutes.

Examples (OF):

  • The color of the car is blue.
  • She is a friend of mine.
  • I drank a cup of coffee.
  • It is the first day of the month.

50.title: Question Formation (with Auxiliaries)
50.content:
The structure for asking most questions in English is very consistent. For simple present and simple past tenses, you must use an auxiliary verb (do, does, did). This is called inversion, where the auxiliary verb comes before the subject.

The Core Structure (QWASM):

(Wh-) + Auxiliary + Subject + Base Verb?

Common Errors to Avoid

  1. Forgetting the Auxiliary: You cannot just add a question mark to a statement. The auxiliary is required.
    Incorrect: ~What you think?~ → Correct: What do you think?
  2. Mixing Auxiliaries: Never use 'do/does/did' with another auxiliary like 'be' or 'can'.
    Incorrect: ~Why did the server was down?~ → Correct: Why was the server down?
  3. Incorrect Main Verb Form: The main verb after the subject must always be the base form (no -s, -ed, etc.).
    Incorrect: ~Why did the build failed?~ → Correct: Why did the build fail?
  4. Incorrect Subject-Verb Agreement: Use 'does' for third-person singular (he, she, it) and 'do' for all others.
    Incorrect: ~What do this script do?~ → Correct: What does this script do?

10 Examples in Context:

  1. What do you need from me?
  2. Where does this function get its data?
  3. Why did the deployment fail yesterday?
  4. How do these two components interact?
  5. When does the cron job run?
  6. Which button did you click to get that error?
  7. Do you have access to the repository?
  8. Does this ticket have the acceptance criteria?
  9. Did you clear the cache before testing?
  10. How do these values get updated in the database?

51.title: Subject-Verb Agreement in Questions
51.content:
The auxiliary (Do/Does) changes. The main verb stays in the Base Form.

Examples:

  • Does she live here? (Not: lives)
  • Do they know the answer?
  • Does John play soccer?
  • Where does your father work?
  • Did he go to the party? (Not: went)
  • What does it mean?

52.title: Transitive vs. Intransitive Verbs
52.content:
Transitive verbs MUST have a direct object (something receives the action). Intransitive verbs CANNOT have a direct object.

Examples (Transitive):

  • I bought a car. (Correct) / I bought. (Incorrect)
  • She likes pizza.
  • We need more time.
  • He wrote an email.

Examples (Intransitive):

  • The baby cried.
  • The sun rose.
  • We arrived late.
  • It happened yesterday.
  • He died in 1990.

53.title: Verbs of Motion (Manner vs. Path)
53.content:
Manner verbs (go, walk, run) need 'to'. Path verbs (enter, reach, approach) do NOT use 'to'.

Examples:

  • I went to the park.
  • I walked to the station.
  • She entered the room. (No 'to')
  • We reached our destination. (No 'to')
  • He approached the building.
  • They arrived at the hotel. (Exception)
  • Don't go into the cave.

54.title: Reflexive Pronouns
54.content:
Used when the Subject and Object are the same person.

Examples:

  • I cut myself while cooking.
  • He is looking at himself in the mirror.
  • She taught herself Spanish.
  • We enjoyed ourselves at the party.
  • The computer turned itself off.
  • Help yourself to some food.
  • They blame themselves for the mistake.

55.title: Future: Will vs. Going To
55.content:
Both talk about the future, but the use depends on when the decision was made or the evidence available.

Distinction:

  • Will: Spontaneous decisions, promises, or predictions without evidence.
  • Going to: Plans made before speaking, or predictions based on visual evidence.

Examples:

  • (Spontaneous) The phone is ringing. I'll answer it.
  • (Plan) I'm going to visit my parents this weekend.
  • (Promise) I'll send you the email right now.
  • (Evidence) Look at those clouds! It's going to rain.
  • (Prediction) I think cars will fly in the future.
  • (Plan) We are going to launch the beta version next month.
  • (Spontaneous) I forgot my wallet. — Don't worry, I'll pay.
  • (Decision) Okay, I'll take the job.

56.title: Past Perfect Continuous
56.content:
Used for an action that was happening for a period of time before another action in the past occurred. It emphasizes the duration.

Structure:

Subject + had been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I had been working for 10 hours when I finally quit.
  • She was tired because she had been running.
  • They had been trying to fix the bug for days before they found the solution.
  • It had been raining all night, so the ground was wet.
  • How long had you been waiting before the bus arrived?
  • We had been using that software for years before we switched.
  • He had been living in London when the war started.

57.title: Past Habits: 'Used to' vs. 'Would'
57.content:
Both used to and would are used to talk about repeated actions or habits in the past that are no longer true now. However, they have one very important difference.

Using 'Used to'

'Used to' can describe both past actions (e.g., play, go, work) and past states (e.g., be, have, live, believe).

Subject + used to + Base Verb

Using 'Would'

'Would' is only used for past actions. It cannot be used to describe past states. It often has a more nostalgic or story-telling tone.

Subject + would + Base Verb

The Key Difference: Actions vs. States

This is the most important rule. For actions, you can often use both. For states, you can only use 'used to'.

  • State (Correct): I used to live in a small town.
  • State (Incorrect): I would live in a small town.

Examples:

  • When I was a kid, my dad would read me a story every night. (Action)
  • We used to go to the beach every summer. (Action)
  • I used to have long hair. (State)
  • She used to be very shy. (State)
  • Every winter, they would build a snowman in the yard. (Action)
  • He didn't use to like coffee, but now he loves it. (Negative state)
  • There used to be a movie theater on this street. (State of existence)
  • Before I got this job, I would wake up late every day. (Action)
  • Did you use to play an instrument? (Question about a past habit)
  • My grandfather would always tell the same jokes. (Action)

59.title: Basic Modal Verbs
59.content:
Modal Verbs express ability, permission, obligation, advice, or possibility. They are auxiliary verbs that always accompany a base verb (e.g., 'go', 'do', 'be') and they do not change form for the subject (no '-s' for third person).

Structure:

Subject + modal + Base Verb

Common Modals:

  • Can: (Ability, Permission)
    I can fix this bug right now.
    You can't deploy this until it's tested.
  • Could: (Past Ability, Polite Request)
    Could you help me with this file?
    I couldn't access the server yesterday.
  • May: (Formal Permission, Possibility)
    This may cause a side effect we haven't seen.
    You may not leave until the process is complete.
  • Might: (Possibility)
    We might need to refactor this class later.
    It might not be the best solution, but it works.
  • Must: (Strong Obligation, Prohibition)
    You must update the documentation.
    You mustn't push code directly to the main branch.
  • Should: (Advice, Expectation)
    You should test your code before committing.
    We shouldn't wait until the last minute.
  • Will: (Future Action, Willingness)
    I'll call you back in five minutes.
    The system won't accept the new password.
  • Would: (Polite Request, Hypothetical)
    Would you mind sending me the file?
    I wouldn't do that if I were you.

60.title: Imperative Sentences
60.content:
Used for orders, instructions, or advice. No subject is used.

Examples:

  • Open the door.
  • Don't touch that!
  • Be quiet.
  • Turn left at the corner.
  • Please help me.
  • Have a nice day.
  • Click the save button.

61.title: Existential 'There' (There is/are)
61.content:
Indicates existence. The verb agrees with the noun that follows.

Examples:

  • There is a pen on the table.
  • There are two cars outside.
  • There was a problem yesterday.
  • There were many people at the party.
  • Is there a bathroom here?
  • There has been an accident.
  • There will be rain tomorrow.

62.title: Want/Need + Object + Infinitive
62.content:
Used when you want SOMEONE ELSE to do something.

Structure:

Subject + Want + Person + to + Verb

Examples:

  • I want you to clean your room.
  • She needs him to sign the document.
  • He asked me to help.
  • Do you want us to wait?
  • The teacher told the students to sit down.
  • I didn't expect them to arrive so early.

63.title: Noun Clauses (What... is...)
63.content:
Using a clause starting with 'What' as the subject for emphasis.

Examples:

  • What I need is a vacation.
  • What he said was true.
  • What happened is a mystery.
  • What you see is what you get.
  • What confuses me is the last step.
  • What I like about her is her honesty.
  • All I want is some peace and quiet.

64.title: Gerund as Subject
64.content:
Using a Verb-ing as the main subject of the sentence. It is always singular.

Examples:

  • Smoking is bad for your health.
  • Learning English takes time.
  • Swimming is good exercise.
  • Eating vegetables is important.
  • Reading books helps your vocabulary.
  • Finding a job is difficult.
  • Flying makes me nervous.

65.title: Zero Conditional
65.content:
The Zero Conditional is used for general truths, facts, and scientific laws. It describes a result that always happens if a condition is met.

Structure:

If/When + Present Simple, ... Present Simple

Examples:

  • If you click this button, it opens a modal.
  • If the server receives too many requests, it gets slow.
  • When a user enters the wrong password, the system shows an error message.
  • If water reaches 100 degrees Celsius, it boils.
  • Plants die if they don't get enough water.
  • When I have a lot of work, I get stressed.

66.title: Prepositions at the End of Questions
66.content:
In English, it is natural to put the preposition at the end.

Examples:

  • What are you looking at?
  • Who are you waiting for?
  • Where do you come from?
  • Who are you talking to?
  • What is he afraid of?
  • What are you thinking about?
  • Who does this belong to?
  • What music are you listening to?

67.title: 'How long has it been since...?'
67.content:
Used to ask about the time elapsed since a past event. The clause following 'since' must be in the Past Simple.

Structure:

How long has it been since + Subject + Past Simple?

Examples:

  • How long has it been since we last met?
  • How long has it been since you visited home?
  • How long has it been since he quit his job?
  • It has been two years since I saw her.
  • Has it been long since you arrived?
  • How long has it been since the server was updated?

68.title: Collective Nouns
68.content:
Collective nouns refer to a group of people or things. The verb agreement depends on the variety of English you are speaking.

The Rule: American vs. British

  • American English: Collective nouns are treated as Singular. The group acts as one unit.
    The team is winning.
  • British English: They can be Plural if focusing on individual members.
    The team are winning.

Examples (Standard American Usage):

  • The team is ready for the sprint. (Not 'are')
  • Our company has a strict security policy.
  • The government has released new regulations.
  • The committee decides on the budget today.
  • The staff is in a meeting.
  • The audience was very engaged during the demo.
  • The public needs to be informed.
  • The class starts at 9:00 AM.
  • A crowd was gathering outside.
  • My family lives in another city.

Important Exceptions (Always Plural):

  • The police are investigating the incident.
  • People are complaining about the bug.

69.title: Extreme (Non-Gradable) Adjectives
69.content:
Adjectives that mean 'very + adjective'. Use 'absolutely', not 'very'.

Examples:

  • Cold → Freezing
  • Hot → Boiling
  • Big → Huge / Enormous
  • Small → Tiny
  • Good → Amazing / Fantastic
  • Bad → Terrible / Awful
  • Tired → Exhausted
  • Hungry → Starving
  • Funny → Hilarious
  • Dirty → Filthy

70.title: Prepositional Adjectives
70.content:
Many adjectives must be followed by a specific preposition to be grammatically correct. These combinations (collocations) should be learned as fixed phrases, as the adjective dictates which preposition to use.

Structure:

... Adjective + Preposition

Examples:

  • I'm responsible for deploying the changes.
  • She is good at solving complex problems.
  • This component is similar to the old one.
  • Are you aware of the new security policy?
  • He is very interested in machine learning.
  • This method is different from the one we used before.
  • Don't be afraid of asking questions.

71.title: Separable Phrasal Verbs
71.content:
If the object is a pronoun (it, them, him), it MUST go in the middle.

Examples:

  • Turn it on. (Correct) / Turn on it. (Incorrect)
  • Pick him up.
  • Put it away.
  • Take it off.
  • Write it down.
  • Throw it away.
  • Look it up.
  • I woke her up.

72.title: Indefinite Pronouns (Everyone, Nobody)
72.content:
Words like everyone, somebody, nobody, anyone are grammatically SINGULAR.

Examples:

  • Everyone is here. (Not: are)
  • Somebody has forgotten their bag.
  • Nobody knows the answer.
  • Is anyone home?
  • Nothing happened.
  • Everything was ready.
  • Everyone likes pizza.

73.title: Comparisons of Equality (as...as)
73.content:
Used to show two things are equal. In negative sentences ('not as...as'), it means the first thing is less than the second.

Structure:

as + Adj/Adv + as

Examples:

  • She is as tall as her brother.
  • This code is as efficient as the old one.
  • I can run as fast as you.
  • It is not as expensive as I thought.
  • Please come as soon as possible.
  • He doesn't work as hard as she does.
  • The movie wasn't as good as the book.

74.title: Inversion for Emphasis
74.content:
Formal structure using negative adverbs (Never, Rarely, Hardly) at the start. Invert Subject and Auxiliary.

Examples:

  • Never have I seen such a thing.
  • Rarely do we eat out.
  • Not only is he smart, but he is also kind.
  • Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang.
  • Little did he know about the surprise.
  • Under no circumstances should you open this door.

75.title: Cleft Sentences (It is... that...)
75.content:
Used to emphasize a specific part of the sentence.

Examples:

  • It was John who broke the window. (Not Peter)
  • It is rain that we need.
  • It was yesterday that I saw her.
  • It is your attitude that implies a problem.
  • It was in London that they met.
  • It was the dog that ate my homework.

76.title: Participle Adjectives (-ed vs. -ing)
76.content:
-ed = Feeling. -ing = Cause.

Examples:

  • I am bored. / The movie is boring.
  • She is excited. / The news is exciting.
  • He is tired. / The work is tiring.
  • I am interested. / The book is interesting.
  • We are confused. / The instructions are confusing.
  • They were shocked. / The accident was shocking.
  • I felt embarrassed. / The situation was embarrassing.

77.title: Agreement with 'So' and 'Too'
77.content:
Agreeing with positive statements.

Structure:

So + Aux + Subject
Subject + Aux + too

Examples:

  • I am happy. → So am I. / I am too.
  • She loves pizza. → So do I. / I do too.
  • He went home. → So did we. / We did too.
  • They can swim. → So can he. / He can too.
  • I have finished. → So have I. / I have too.
  • I will go. → So will she. / She will too.

78.title: Exclamations with 'What a' and 'How'
78.content:
To make exclamations, use What a/an... before a (adjective +) singular countable noun, and How... before an adjective or adverb.

Structure:

What a/an + (Adj) + Noun!
How + Adjective/Adverb!

Examples:

  • What a terrible bug!
  • What an elegant solution!
  • How inefficient this query is!
  • How quickly he works!

79.title: Prepositional Verbs
79.content:
Verbs that always go with a specific preposition.

Examples:

  • Listen to music.
  • Wait for me.
  • Look at the board.
  • Agree with someone.
  • Depend on the weather.
  • Talk to your boss.
  • Think about the future.
  • Belong to a club.
  • Laugh at a joke.
  • Believe in ghosts.

80.title: Preferences: 'Prefer' vs. 'Would Prefer'
80.content:
While both express preference, they are used in different contexts. The main distinction is general habits vs. specific situations.

'Prefer' (General Preferences)

Use prefer to talk about habits or what you like in general. It follows two main patterns:

1. Comparing nouns/activities:
prefer + [Noun/Verb-ing] + to + [Noun/Verb-ing]

2. Stating a preference:
prefer + [to + Verb] OR [Verb-ing]

'Would Prefer' (Specific Preferences)

Use would prefer (or 'd prefer) for a choice in a specific situation, right now or in the near future. It is more polite and formal than 'want'.

'd prefer + [to + Verb]

Quick Note: The 'Would Rather' Difference

'Would rather' is also for specific preferences, but it is always followed by the base verb (without 'to').
• Compare: I'd prefer to go. vs. I'd rather go.

10 Examples:

  • (General) She generally prefers coffee to tea.
  • (Specific) Thanks for the offer, but tonight I'd prefer to stay home.
  • (General) I prefer working in a team to working alone.
  • (Specific Question) Would you prefer to have the meeting now or later?
  • (General) Many developers prefer to use dark mode.
  • (Specific Negative) He'd prefer not to discuss the issue right now.
  • (General) For this project, they prefer Python to Java.
  • (Specific & Polite) Where would you prefer to sit?
  • (General Negative) I don't prefer spicy food.
  • (Specific) We'd prefer to finish the deployment before we leave.

81.title: Impersonal Sentences
81.content:
Using 'It' or 'They' for general statements.

Examples:

  • It is raining.
  • It is hard to learn Chinese.
  • It is important to sleep well.
  • It seems that he is angry.
  • It takes time to fix this.
  • They say love is blind.
  • They sell good coffee here.

82.title: Connectors of Cause & Effect
82.content:
Connectors link ideas. Cause (Reason) vs Effect (Result).

Examples:

  • (Cause) I stayed home because it was raining.
  • (Effect) It was raining, so I stayed home.
  • (Cause) Since we have time, let's review the code.
  • (Effect) The server crashed; therefore, the site is down.
  • (Cause) Due to the bad weather, flights were cancelled.
  • (Effect) He forgot his keys; consequently, he couldn't enter.
  • (Cause) As it is late, we should go.

83.title: Connectors for Adding Information
83.content:
Used to add more points to an argument. Common ones are: Also, Furthermore, Moreover, In addition, Besides.

Examples:

  • She speaks French. Also, she knows Spanish.
  • In addition to coding, he designs the UI.
  • The hotel is cheap. Furthermore, it is close to the beach.
  • I don't want to go. Besides, I have no money.
  • He is intelligent and hardworking as well.
  • Moreover, the data shows a positive trend.
  • It acts as a server and also as a client.

84.title: The Adverb 'Even' for Emphasis
84.content:
Means 'incluso' or 'hasta'.

Examples:

  • Even a child can understand this.
  • He didn't even call me. (Ni siquiera)
  • It is even colder today.
  • I work every day, even on Sundays.
  • Everyone passed, even John.
  • He doesn't even know my name.
  • She was even more beautiful than before.

85.title: 'Don't have to' vs. 'Mustn't'
85.content:
Don't have to = No obligation (You can do it if you want, but it's not required).
Mustn't = Prohibition (It is forbidden).

Examples (No Obligation):

  • You don't have to pay; it's free.
  • She doesn't have to come to the meeting.
  • We don't have to finish this today.
  • I didn't have to wear a uniform at my old school.

Examples (Prohibition):

  • You mustn't smoke in here.
  • We mustn't tell anyone the password.
  • He mustn't forget his medication.
  • Visitors mustn't touch the art.

86.title: Questions: 'What... like?' vs. 'How is...?'
86.content:
What is X like? asks for a description of personality or characteristics (permanent).
How is X? asks about health, mood, or current state (temporary).

Examples:

  • A: What is the new boss like? B: He is strict but fair. (Description)
  • A: How is the new boss? B: He is stressed today. (State)
  • A: What was the weather like? B: It was rainy and cold.
  • A: How is your mother? B: She is feeling much better, thanks.
  • A: What is your city like? B: It's noisy and crowded.
  • A: How was the party? B: It was fun! (Experience)

87.title: Compound Nouns: Open & Closed
87.content:
A Compound Noun is a single noun created from two or more words. This modal covers the two most common types: open (written separately) and closed (written as one word).

Pluralization Rule

For both open and closed compound nouns, the plural is almost always formed by adding -s to the very end of the complete word.

A) Open Compound Nouns (two words)

These are two separate words that function as a single unit.

  • The bus stop is just around the corner.
  • I can't find a parking space anywhere.
  • We're having dinner in the living room tonight.
  • You'll need your credit card to pay for that.
  • Is there a post office near here?

B) Closed Compound Nouns (one word)

These words have fused into a single word over time.

  • My keyboard stopped working, so I can't type.
  • Don't forget to pack your toothbrush before the trip.
  • I need to get some sunscreen before we go to the beach.
  • The kids are playing football outside.
  • Could you turn on the bedroom light, please?

88.title: Possessive Pronouns (mine, yours, etc.)
88.content:
Replaces 'My + Noun', 'Your + Noun', etc.

Examples:

  • This is my car. → This is mine.
  • Is that your bag? → Is that yours?
  • That is not her phone. → That isn't hers.
  • Our house is big. → Ours is big.
  • Their team won. → Theirs won.
  • His bike is red. His is red. (Same form)
  • A friend of mine.

89.title: Expressing States with 'to be'
89.content:
In English, we use Be + Adjective for feelings/states where Spanish uses 'Tener'.

Examples:

  • I am hungry. (Not: have hunger)
  • She is thirsty.
  • We are cold.
  • He is hot.
  • I am afraid.
  • They are sleepy.
  • You are right. (Tener razón)
  • He is wrong.
  • How old are you? (I am 20)
  • I am lucky.

90.title: Using 'Have Got' for Possession/Obligation
90.content:
Informal alternative to 'have'. Common in British English but widely used in US English for possession.

Structure:

I/You/We/They have got
He/She/It has got

Examples:

  • I've got a new phone. (I have)
  • She's got two brothers. (She has)
  • Have you got any money?
  • We've got to leave now. (Obligation = have to)
  • He hasn't got a clue.
  • You've got to be kidding me!
  • They've got a lot of problems.

91.title: Past Intentions: 'was/were going to'
91.content:
This structure is used to talk about plans, intentions, or predictions in the past that did not happen for some reason. It's the past tense of 'be going to'.

Structure:

Subject + was/were + going to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I was going to do it, but I forgot.
  • She was going to call you, but her phone died.
  • They were going to launch the feature, but they found a critical bug.
  • He was going to tell you, but it wasn't necessary.
  • We were going to write it down, but we didn't know where.
  • It was going to be a sunny day, but then it started raining.

92.title: Idiomatic Expressions (Idioms)
92.content:
An idiom is a common phrase or expression whose meaning cannot be understood from the literal definition of its individual words. They are a type of figure of speech and must be learned as a whole unit.

Idioms do not fit into a single grammatical category; they can function as verbs, nouns, or entire clauses within a sentence.

Examples:

  • (To forget something) It completely slipped my mind.
  • (To face a difficult situation with courage) You just have to bite the bullet.
  • (Something is very easy) Don't worry, the test will be a piece of cake.
  • (A problem that seems bad at first but results in something good) Losing that job was a blessing in disguise.
  • (To study hard) I have to go home and hit the books.

93.title: Causative 'Have'
93.content:
The Causative 'Have' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them. It is the natural way to talk about services you pay for or actions you delegate.

For example, 'I cut my hair' implies you did it yourself. 'I had my hair cut' implies you went to a hairdresser. This structure is also used for negative events that happen *to* the subject.

Structure:

Subject + have (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • (Service) I'm going to have my hair cut tomorrow.
  • (Service) We are having our house painted next month.
  • (Service) She needs to have her eyes checked.
  • (Service) He has his windows cleaned once a month.
  • (Service) The company had a new app developed.
  • (Negative Event) I had my wallet stolen on the subway.

94.title: Mathematical Operations & Symbols
94.content:
In English, mathematical operations are expressed with specific words. Knowing these terms is essential for discussing calculations clearly.

Common Operations:

  • Addition (+)
    5 + 3 = 8 is read as 'five plus three equals eight'.
  • Subtraction (-)
    10 - 4 = 6 is read as 'ten minus four equals six'.
  • Multiplication (× or *)
    5 × 8 = 40 is read as 'five times eight is forty'. You can also say 'multiplied by'.
  • Division (÷ or /)
    20 ÷ 4 = 5 is read as 'twenty divided by four equals five'.
  • Equality (=)
    The symbol = is called the 'equals sign'. In speech, you can say 'equals' or 'is'.
  • Parentheses ()
    (2 + 3) × 4 is read as 'two plus three in parentheses, times four'.

95.title: Causative 'Get' (Get something done)
95.content:
The Causative 'Get' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them, often by paying for a service. It's a common and slightly more informal alternative to the 'Causative Have'.

The focus is on the action being completed, not on who performs it.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I need to get my car fixed.
  • She got her phone repaired after she dropped it.
  • We are getting our house painted next week.
  • You should get your suit cleaned before the wedding.
  • Where can I get this document translated?
  • He got a pizza delivered for dinner.

96.title: Citing & Conditions: According to vs. Based on vs. Depending on
96.content:
These phrases are often confused but have distinct meanings for expressing sources, reasons, or conditions.

Key Differences:

  • According to... is used to cite a source of information. You are reporting what someone or something else has said.
    According to the weather forecast, it's going to rain tomorrow.
  • Based on... is used to explain the reason, evidence, or criteria for a decision or action.
    The team was chosen based on their performance.
  • Depending on... is used to show that a result or action is subject to a variable or condition.
    We might go to the park, depending on the weather.

More Examples:

  • [Citing Source] According to the article, the company is doing well.
  • [Stating Criteria] We organize the files based on the project name.
  • [Expressing Condition] The price can change depending on availability.

Common Error: Do not use 'according to me'. The correct phrase is 'in my opinion'.

97.title: Common Adjective + Gerund Structures
97.content:
A few common and practical English adjectives and expressions are followed directly by a Gerund (-ing form) instead of an infinitive. These structures must be memorized as fixed patterns.

Key Structures:

  • busy + doing something
    Used to say that you are occupied with an activity.
    She is busy preparing for her final exams.
  • worth + doing something
    Used to say that something is useful, enjoyable, or beneficial to do.
    The new feature is worth trying.
  • it's no use / it's no good + doing something
    Used to say that an action is pointless or will not have a successful result.
    It's no use complaining about the problem; we need to fix it.

More Examples:

  • I was too busy answering emails to join the call.
  • This museum is definitely worth visiting while you're in the city.
  • It's no good trying to convince him; his mind is made up.

98.title: Mixed Conditionals
98.content:
Mixed Conditionals combine parts of different conditional types, usually the Second and Third. They are used when the time of the condition is different from the time of the result. This creates a link between the past and the present, or the present and the past.

Type 1: Past Condition → Present Result

This type describes a hypothetical past action (that didn't happen) and its imaginary result in the present.

If + Past Perfect, ... would + Base Verb

  • If I had taken that job, I would be rich now.
  • You wouldn't be so tired if you had gone to bed earlier last night.
  • If we had bought the tickets, we would be at the concert right now.

Type 2: Present Condition → Past Result

This type describes a hypothetical present state (that isn't true) and its imaginary result in the past. This is less common.

If + Past Simple, ... would have + Past Participle

  • If I were a better programmer, I would have written that script myself.
  • If he wasn't so shy, he would have asked her out yesterday.
  • If I spoke French, I would have understood them at the meeting.

99.title: Compound Nouns: Hyphenated
99.content:
Hyphenated Compound Nouns use hyphens (-) to connect words, often to define roles, relationships, or to create a single, clear concept and avoid ambiguity.

The Plural Rule (Important!)

This is the key difference: the plural -s is added to the primary noun in the phrase, not to the end of the entire word. This is the most significant word in the compound.

Examples:

  • My mother-in-law is coming to visit for the weekend.
  • He is the editor-in-chief of a famous newspaper.
  • A passer-by found the lost wallet on the street.

Plural Examples in Action:

  • I have three sisters-in-law, and they are all very nice.
  • Several passers-by stopped to help after the accident.
  • The newspaper has had many editors-in-chief over the years.

100.title: Talking About Money: North America & Beyond
100.content:
Understanding how to talk about money in English involves knowing both the formal terms and the common, everyday slang. This guide focuses on the practical language used in the USA and Canada.

North America (USA & Canada)

The system and language are nearly identical in both countries.

  • Currency: The main unit is the Dollar, and the subunit is the Cent. The decimal separator is always a period (e.g., $10.50).
  • Key Slang: The most common informal word for 'dollar' is buck (singular) or bucks (plural).
  • Saying Prices: For a price like $4.99, the most natural way to say it is 'four ninety-nine'. The words 'dollars' and 'cents' are usually omitted.
  • Canada Specific: Informally, Canadians sometimes use 'Loonie' for the one-dollar coin and 'Toonie' for the two-dollar coin.

Bonus: Contrast with UK & Europe

  • United Kingdom: Currency is the Pound (£), with the slang term quid. The subunit is Pence (p). £10.50 is said 'ten pounds fifty' or 'ten fifty'.
  • Eurozone: Currency is the Euro (€). €10.50 is 'ten euros fifty'. Many European countries use a comma as a decimal separator in writing (10,50€).

10 Common Examples (US/Canada):

  • The total comes to twenty-five fifty.
  • Do you have anything for around ten bucks?
  • A coffee here costs about three seventy-five.
  • Can I borrow a couple of bucks for the vending machine?
  • You owe me twenty bucks from dinner last night.
  • This shirt is on sale—it's only twelve ninety-nine.
  • All I have is a fifty-dollar bill; do you have change?
  • The tickets were a hundred and fifty dollars each. (formal/emphatic)
  • Is it possible to pay in cash?
  • I'm trying to save some money for my vacation.

101.title: The Word 'Either': 3 Key Uses
101.content:
Either is a versatile word used to talk about choices between two options and to agree with negative statements. Its grammatical function—and therefore its meaning—changes depending on how it's used in a sentence.

The 3 Main Functions of 'Either':

1. As a Determiner or Pronoun (A choice of one from two)

Used to mean 'one or the other of two people or things'. It can be placed before a singular noun (determiner) or stand on its own (pronoun).

  • You can park on either side of the street.
  • I don't mind which one we watch; either movie is fine with me.
  • A: 'Which server should we use?' B: 'Either of the servers has enough capacity.'
  • A: 'Would you like the report in PDF or DOCX format?' B: 'Either is fine, thank you.'

2. As a Conjunction (Paired with 'or')

Used in the structure either ... or ... to present two exclusive options or possibilities.

either + [Option A] + or + [Option B]

  • We can either start the meeting now or wait for him.
  • The bug is either in the front-end or in the back-end logic.
  • For this to work, either the configuration needs to be updated or the code must be changed.
  • You must either accept the terms or reject them completely.

3. As an Adverb (Negative Agreement)

Used at the end of a negative sentence to show agreement. It is the negative equivalent of 'too' or 'also' and means 'también no' or 'tampoco'.

Negative Statement. ... negative auxiliary ... either.

  • A: 'I don't understand this issue.' B: 'I don't understand it either.'
  • If you don't go to the meeting, then I won't go either.
  • She couldn't find the solution, and her colleague couldn't either.
  • The first server isn't responding, and the backup server isn't working either.

102.title: Expressing Duration (last, take, for, during)
102.content:
To talk about how long something takes, we use specific verbs and prepositions. It's vital to distinguish between verbs (the action) and nouns (the concept), and to know when to use 'for' or 'during'.

Key Differences Explained

  • Verbs (last / take / be...long): These describe the action of time passing. 'Last' is a direct translation of 'durar'. 'Take' focuses on the time required. 'Be...long' describes the length.
    The meeting will last one hour. / It takes one hour. / It is one hour long.
  • Noun (duration): This is the name of the concept. It is more formal and is used to talk about the measurement of time.
    The duration of the meeting is one hour.
  • Prepositions (for / during): 'For' specifies the length of time (a quantity). 'During' specifies when something happens within a named period or event.
    He spoke for ten minutes during the presentation.

10 Common Examples:

  1. The presentation will last about 45 minutes.
  2. How long will the maintenance window be?
  3. It takes about five minutes to walk from the station.
  4. What is the total duration of the project?
  5. We worked on that specific feature for three weeks.
  6. He lost his internet connection during the important call.
  7. Don't worry, the update shouldn't take long to install.
  8. The power outage yesterday lasted for nearly two hours.
  9. The movie is two and a half hours long.
  10. I can't take calls during the workday, but I can talk for an hour after 6 PM.

103.title: Know vs. Get to Know vs. Meet
103.content:
These verbs relate to familiarity but are often confused. The key difference is state vs. process.

To Know describes a state of existing familiarity. To Get to Know describes the process of acquiring that familiarity over time. To Meet is used only for the first introduction with a person.

Conceptual Structure:

To Know = State (Familiarity already exists)
To Get to Know = Process (Acquiring familiarity)
To Meet = Action (First introduction)

Examples: 'To Know' (State)

  • I know this city well.
  • She already knows the new project manager.
  • Do you know how this API works?

Examples: 'Get to Know' (Process)

  • I am getting to know this city. (Process over time)
  • We need to get to know our new team members.
  • It took a while to get to know the new system.

Examples: 'Meet' (First Introduction)

  • I met your brother yesterday. (The first time)
  • It's nice to meet you.
  • We met at the conference last week.

104.title: Omitting Relative Pronouns (that, who, which)
104.content:
You can often omit the relative pronouns that, who, or which to sound more natural. The rule depends on what word follows the pronoun.

The simple trick: Look at the word immediately after the pronoun.

  • If the next word is a Noun or Pronoun (I, you, she, the team), the relative pronoun is optional.
  • If the next word is a Verb (is, lives, makes), the relative pronoun is mandatory.

Structure:

Case 1 (Optional):
...Noun + (that/who) + Subject + Verb ...

Case 2 (Mandatory):
...Noun + that/who + Verb ...

Examples (Case 1: Optional - Next word is a Subject)

  • The movie (that) we watched was amazing.
  • The woman (who) I met is the new manager.
  • I love the car (that) she bought.
  • The code (which) you wrote is very clean.

Examples (Case 2: Mandatory - Next word is a Verb)

  • The man who lives next door is a doctor.
  • I work for a company that makes software.
  • Can you pass me the phone that is on the table?
  • She's the developer who speaks three languages.

105.title: Quantifiers: A Few vs. A Little vs. A Bit
105.content:
The key difference between these quantifiers depends on whether the noun is countable (things you can count, like apples, minutes, friends) or uncountable (things you can't count, like water, time, money).

A few is used only for countables. A little and a bit are used only for uncountables. 'A bit' is generally more informal than 'a little'.

Structure:

1. For Countable Nouns (Plural):
A few + [Countable Noun]
A few of + [the/my/those... Noun]

2. For Uncountable Nouns (Singular):
A little + [Uncountable Noun]
A little of + [the/my/that... Noun]

3. For Uncountable Nouns (Informal):
A bit of + [Uncountable Noun]

Examples: 'A Few' (Countable)

  • I need a few minutes.
  • She has a few good ideas.
  • A few of my friends are coming.
  • Can I try a few of those grapes?

Examples: 'A Little' (Uncountable)

  • We need a little help with this.
  • There's a little traffic this morning.
  • He spent a little of the money you gave him.
  • I understood a little of it.

Examples: 'A Bit' (Informal Uncountable)

  • I have a bit of money left.
  • We're in a bit of trouble.
  • I'm a bit tired. (Modifying an adjective)
  • Could you wait a bit? (Modifying a verb)

106.title: Common Expressions with 'IN'
106.content:
There are many fixed English expressions (idioms) that start with the preposition 'in'. These phrases often do not have a literal translation and must be memorized as a complete unit.

Structure (Lexical):

[Subject] + [Verb] + [IN-Expression]

Common Expressions & Examples:

  • in a good mood / in a bad mood (de buen/mal humor)
    The boss is in a good mood today.
  • in a hurry / in a rush (con prisa)
    Sorry, I can't talk, I'm in a hurry.
  • in love (with) (enamorado de)
    They are completely in love with each other.
  • in trouble (en problemas)
    He is in trouble for missing the deadline.
  • in charge (of) (a cargo de)
    She is in charge of the entire department.
  • in time (a tiempo)
    We arrived in time to catch the flight.
  • in the mood (for) (con ganas de)
    I'm not in the mood for a meeting right now.
  • in the way (estorbando / en medio)
    Could you move? You're in the way.
  • in touch (with) (en contacto con)
    Let's stay in touch after the project.
  • in debt (endeudado)
    The company is in debt after the expansion.
  • in shape (en forma física)
    I need to exercise more to stay in shape.
  • in danger (en peligro)
    The data is in danger of being corrupted.

107.title: The 'Get-Passive' Construction
107.content:
The 'Get-Passive' is an alternative to the standard 'be-passive' (e.g., 'it was broken'). It is very common in spoken, informal English.

While the 'be-passive' often describes a state, the 'get-passive' is used to emphasize the process, event, or change of state, especially one that is accidental, sudden, or negative.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Past Participle

Examples:

  • The manager got fired after the audit.
  • Employees get paid on the last Friday of the month.
  • They got married in a small ceremony.
  • A passenger got hurt during the turbulence.
  • The document gets saved automatically every five minutes.
  • The prototype got broken during testing.
  • My wallet got stolen yesterday.
  • The computer needs to get fixed.
  • The report must get finished by the deadline.
  • The loan application finally got approved.

108.title: Expressing 'Faltar' (To Miss, Lack, Be Left, etc)
108.content:
The Spanish verb 'faltar' has many meanings. In English, the correct word depends entirely on the context, such as absence, lack of something, or remaining time.

1. Absence (Not Attending)

This context differentiates between intention.

  • To miss (Involuntary): Used when you 'faltas' involuntarily (sickness, delay, obligation).
    She missed the meeting because she was sick.
    Hurry up or you'll miss the bus!
  • To skip (Intentional): Used when you 'faltas' intentionally (you decided not to go).
    I decided to skip the class today.
    Let's skip the introduction and get to the point.

2. Carency (Lack of Something)

  • To be missing (Lost/Not present): Used when an item should be present but is not.
    My keys are missing.
    A page is missing from this book.
  • To be short (on/of) (Not enough): Used when you don't have a sufficient amount.
    We're short on milk. Can you buy some?
    I'm $5 short to buy the ticket.
  • To be out of (Depleted): Used when the supply is completely gone.
    We're out of sugar.
    I can't print. The printer is out of paper.
  • To lack (Formal Carency): A more formal verb for a general carency.
    He lacks the confidence to speak in public.
    The report lacks clear data.

3. Time Remaining

  • ...left (Remaining): The most common structure for remaining time or quantity.
    There are ten minutes left.
    How much time do we have left?
  • ...to go (Countdown): Used informally to count down to a deadline or event.
    Five minutes to go!
    Two more weeks to go.

109.title: Common 'Work' Compounds
109.content:
These four 'Work' compounds are fundamental in business and technology, but they are often confused. Workaround, Workflow, Workload, and Workspace each refer to a very specific concept.

Workaround

A temporary or alternative solution used to bypass a problem or limitation.

  • The update has a bug, but we found a workaround.
  • We need a quick workaround until the system is fixed.
  • This workaround is not perfect, but it lets us finish the job.

Workflow

The sequence of steps or processes required to complete a specific task or job.

  • Our team needs a more efficient workflow.
  • The new software improved our workflow.
  • Please follow the steps in the approved workflow.

Workload

The total amount of work that a person or machine is expected to do in a specific period.

  • My workload is very heavy this month.
  • The manager tried to balance the team's workload.
  • I cannot accept more tasks due to my current workload.

Workspace

The physical area (like a desk or office) or the digital environment where work is done.

  • I need to organize my workspace.
  • The company provides a comfortable workspace.
  • This software offers a customizable digital workspace.

110.title: Pronouncing '0': Zero vs. Oh
110.content:
The pronunciation of the digit '0' depends on the context. Use 'zero' for formal or mathematical contexts, and 'oh' (like the letter 'O') for informal sequences like phone or room numbers.

When to Say 'Zero' (Formal / Math)

Use 'zero' (phonetically: /ˈzɪroʊ/) when you are talking about the number itself, in mathematics, science, or when precision is important.

  • The temperature is 0 degrees. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/...)
  • Any number multiplied by 0 is 0. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/.../ˈzɪroʊ/.)
  • The project has a 0% chance of failure. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/ percent...)
  • The countdown is: three, two, one, 0. (.../ˈzɪroʊ/.)
  • The final score was two to 0. (...two to /ˈzɪroʊ/.)

When to Say 'Oh' (Informal / Sequences)

Use 'oh' (phonetically: /oʊ/) when the '0' is just one digit in a longer, informal string of numbers. This is faster and more common in daily speech.

  • His number is (555) 890-0201. (...eight-nine-/oʊ/... /oʊ/-two-/oʊ/-one.)
  • Please go to Room 405. (...room four-/oʊ/-five.)
  • She was born in 1908. (...nineteen-/oʊ/-eight.)
  • I am using version 32.0.1. (...thirty-two point /oʊ/ point one.)
  • The meeting is at 08:00. (...at /oʊ/-eight-hundred.)

111.title: Preposition Stranding (Questions)
111.content:
In English, when a question involves a verb + preposition, the preposition usually moves to the very end of the sentence. This is natural and grammatically correct.

Structure:

Question Word + [Aux] + [Subject] + Verb + Preposition?

Examples:

  • (I am listening to the radio.)
    → What are you listening to?
  • (She is thinking about the project.)
    → What is she thinking about?
  • (We are waiting for our boss.)
    → Who are you waiting for?
  • (He relies on this data.)
    → What data does he rely on?
  • (You asked for a new report.)
    → What did you ask for?
  • (We are working on a bug fix.)
    → What are you working on?
  • (She is looking at the logs.)
    → What is she looking at?
  • (It depends on the configuration.)
    → What does it depend on?
  • (We paid for the license.)
    → What did you pay for?
  • (You should focus on the backend.)
    → What should I focus on?
  • (This laptop belongs to me.)
    → Who does this laptop belong to?
  • (The script searches for a specific string.)
    → What does the script search for?
  • (He cares about performance.)
    → What does he care about?
  • (They were laughing at the meme.)
    → What were they laughing at?
  • (We argued about the design.)
    → What did you argue about?
  • (The system consists of three modules.)
    → What does the system consist of?
  • (I don't agree with that policy.)
    → What don't you agree with?
  • (He is worried about the deadline.)
